16056106.review:
[h1]TLDR; Bottom-line[/h1]
This game is a [b]Simplified Side Scrolling Arcade Spectacle Brawler[/b]. You only have two buttons: Left-attack and Right-attack. The main mechanic is virtually identical to [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/264200]One Finger Death Punch[/url], but in Kung Fury you only have [b] ONE MODE[/b] and [b]ONE STAGE[/b]. If this is too little content for you then don't bother. If you want more variety, take a look at One Finger Death Punch. If you liked the movie and want to play as the badass Kung Fury though, this game is still pretty damn fun. I say this game is worth the asking price of $2.

[h1]Sample Gameplay[/h1]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=454796042

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
The game is a [b]simplified[/b] 2D side scrolling brawler. You have two buttons: [L] Left-Attack and [R] Right-Attack. If enemies come from the left, you hit Left-Attack, if they come from the right you hit Right-Attack. The most common enemy will die in one hit, but other enemies require different combinations of [L] or [R] to defeat. For example the German officer requires you to hit him twice; the blonde girls in white require you to hit them three times in an alternating fashion (From left [L][R][L], from right [R][L][R]).

As for controls you have the choice of using the keyboard keys [A]/[D], or [<-][->], or mouse left-click/right-click. Controllers are also supported, with all the buttons on the left bound to left attack, and all the right buttons bound to right attack. You cannot rebind the keys as there is no options menu.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Kung Fury is a hyper-stylized 2D side-scroller with an older 1980s pixelated art-style. The viewing area of the game is presented like an old arcade cabinet with a non-flat CRT monitor. The presentation of the game is meant to match the theme of the movie, so if you didn't like the movie or the old CRT look then chances are you won't like the game itself.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Go watch the [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/374570/]movie[/url].
The game itself does not have a story, but in order to appreciate this game I recommend watching the movie. It's FREE!

As a side note the game is based on one particular fight scene in the movie, where Kung Fury fights from right to left (side scrolling).

[h1]PC Master Race Issues[/h1]
There is no options menu. You cannot rebind your keys (though there are a fair amount of default bindings to choose from), and you cannot change your resolution or anything else. The game defaults to fullscreen, but you can change it to window mode by pressing [ALT]+[ENTER]. This is sparse to say the least, and if you are particularly sensitive to missing features such as an options menu, then don't waste your time.

18Mb of game data? here goes another over night download I thought, my dial up just won't be able to take it and heaven forbid anyone in the house tries to make a phone call and drop the connection on me.

The graphics was also a concern but then I remembered my pc has a turbo button so I should be safe.

Overall I do enjoy the game even though it is extremely system resource intensive, colours are bright and the pixel quality is amazing, I swear, graphics are so damn good now it's hard to tell the difference between watching my video tapes and people in video games, they are so life like.

My only 3 gripes about this game was the fast pace of the character movement and the complex control system, I can't understand why games have to use so many buttons these days it just makes the learning curve too steep.
I miss my joystick with fire button mounted on top, I had a real sense of control especially when I sat it on my desk where the suction cups on the bottom could really hold it down.

Lastly I'm really not a fan of this downloading things via a billboard, I prefer to own a physical copy on a 5.25" floppy but it seems this is the way of the future now that all the "new blood" personal computer owners are pushing for.

Based on this information I give this game 5 lightning strikes with 3 cobra bites out of 6 laser raptors.

The game self is not bad made really, you can play it more or less (like the real old 80s arcade games) just for fun in the break times. Its also pretty difficult and also fun to play, Yea it is even harder than One Finger Death Punch.

But why i gave it a down vote?

Its not really that the game is that bad really and i even guess with 2$ its a fair price if you play it "just for fun" (just to compare: One Finger Death Punch are 5$ and has more stuff inside wile Kung Fury are 2$ and is more a weaker (but harder) version of One Finger Death Punch...).

The big problem i really think is that this game doesnt live up the expectations of the movie it is really based on. Just using the left and right button is not that "cool" like in the movie even if the animations are well made, after some minutes you will also see it maybe gives not more than 5-6 attack animation-loops.

As i said,[b] its not a bad voting coz its a bad game,[/b] its a bad voting coz this game doesnt live up the expectations...

I maybe will still play it sometimes if i like to but honestly, to live up the expectations from the movie they should do a better game...

16054317.review:
[h1] Kung Fury: Street Rage [/h1] si tratta di un gioco basato sul film [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/374570/?snr=1_5_1100__1100] Kung Fury [/url],un bel film tributo agli anni 80! Leggero,assurdo e divertente da vedere,tra l'altro lo trovate gratis in streaming su Steam.

Ora parliamo del gioco:

Ero davvero indeciso se consigliarlo o meno ma ho deciso di non farlo e vi spiego il motivo.

Il gioco si prospetta davvero bello,il gameplay è parecchio simile a [b] One Finger Death Punch[/b] ovvero un Beat 'Em Up in stile arcade,dove combatterete con soli due tasti e lo scopo sarà di ottenere più combo possibili per ottenere più punti come un vero gioco arcade.

L'atmosfera rispecchia molto il film e il tema ovvero gli anni 80 e la colonna sonora è fantastica.Ma il gioco presenta delle pecche che sono riuscite a non farmelo piacere.

Prima di tutto il gioco ha come sistema la leaderboard visto che si tratta di un gioco arcade,ovvero ottenete sempre più punti e scavalcate le classifiche ma ecco la pecca..la leaderboard è soltanto offline o con i vostri amici .Quindi non potrete  scalare le classifiche,il che rende il gioco inutile da giocare.

La ripetitività arriva davvero in fretta perché il gioco non contiene nessuna variazione,niente achievement/obiettivi e niente missioni,soltanto un livello infinito.Quindi picchierete e picchierete gente e non otterrete nulla e vi annoierete davvero presto ve lo assicuro con tutto che il Beat 'Em Up è uno dei miei generi preferiti.

La nota positiva è che il prezzo è abbastanza giusto visto che vi viene a costare 1,99 anche se a parer mio ora come ora non li vale.

Grazie per aver letto la recensione e fatemi sapere cosa ne pensate

Clunks and sputters like a real middle-of-the-road licensed game. Is its half-brokenness part of the joke? "It's a licensed game from the 1980s! What did you expect, a masterpiece? You spoiled modern gamer, you." 

To be sure, it's no Total Recall, Hudson Hawk, Top Gun, E.T., Friday the 13th... 16052695.review:
Very simple, One Finger Death Punch-style two-button 80s throwback-themed beat 'em up.
The gameplay is simple, smooth, brawler gameplay extracted to its most basic elements. Two buttons, zero nonsense.Very casual in the sense that you can jump straight into the game very quickly and then leave just as fast when you've had your fill, but still challenging enough to be fun.
Visually, it's your regular 80s arcade-style graphics. If you're into that you won't find anything new here but if you're into 80s arcade games, new probably isn't what you're looking for anyway.
In summary, this game is a good bit of fun. I probably wouldn't pay more than 2 Euros for it but that's exactly how much they're asking.
If you liked Kung Fury, buy this game, you'll like it.
If you're not familiar with Kung Fury but you're into brawlers and/or retro graphics, you'll probably like it too.

16052476.review:
Updated for Arcade Strikes Back: Story mode, voiced by the original cast with new dialogue, and a plotline! It's no longer just going for the high score! New characters to fight with - Barbarianna, who can clear a side with the chain gun every 5 hits, which is awesome; Hackerman, whose ranged weapon knocks back as it charges for a continuous double-damage combo (which often results in wild flailing back and forth as the most effective means of combat); and Triceracop, who...um...seems broken.  

You see, Triceracop uses his trademark crotch shot method of attack...with guns...that has the effective range of Kung Fury's normal attacks. I don't know, maybe he's going for a 100% shot to crotch ratio or something and relies on a close range target... However, the guns have a knockback to them, pushing Triceracop backwards. This is fine, until you encounter the wave of kung-fu women who swap sides when hit. The knockback is strong enough to where you can shoot three times in the same direction and still hit them, but not 100% reliably; and you can still alternate your shot directions to hit them... but not 100% reliably. So when the wave of 8 of these women show up (with 2 robot legs) somewhere around the 3rd wave, if your recoil pushes you to the other side of one of these women and your combo breaks, you get stunned, take a hit, and are suddenly surrounded by multiple women (normally a good problem to have) each one having the potential to break your combo if your recoil puts you in the wrong spot to hit, forcing you to take another hit. The game generously provides Triceracop with more hearts than any other character in the game, which makes it feel like the designers were aware the game mechanic caused unavoidable hits. 

Original Review below:

Watch the short film, then get the game. The movie is 20 minutes of your life well spent. If you play the game 8 times it pays for itself. I mean, arcade games still cost a quarter per credit, right? A genuine arcade feel to this beat-em-up, with surprisingly in-depth technique for a game that uses only 2 buttons. It's a sort of rhythm of the battle thing - go too fast for the action and you'll end up missing the next enemy and take a hit; go too slow and you'll be surrounded quickly and take a hit. The rhythm fluctuates with the density of enemies and their health. You must be the master of the rhythm of the battle if you want the high score. Wait for the enemy to approach, then buffer your inputs so that no time is wasted preparing for the next enemy. Also digging that retrowave soundtrack.

16051928.review:
The movie was an incredible parody of an 80's flick, and this game continues that parody in that like other video games based on hit films in the 80's this was horrible. It's a two button game, with no walking....you just punch left or right to move and it auto targets the enemy closest to you. There's not much skill, and even less variety. 

You punch your way back and fourth across a single level/street and just bash Nazis, Nazis in gas masks, nazi arcade machine robots and nazi female nurses? I guess? The point is, there's not much meat to the game, and no reason to play more than once for about 10 or 15 mins, because by then you have experienced all the game has to offer.

There's no incentive to play any longer, at least if the game had cards, you might find a reason to stay in it, but there's not even that.

One could argue that the game is cheap, and thus not worth complaining about. I of course could respond that at any given time, there is a game on steam cheaper than this and far more enjoyable. Right now there are several indi RPGs for 50 cents less than this...So, 2 bucks is way over priced. This SHOULD be a free game, but even then, there are better free games than this...it's sad really.

16051739.review:
Short Review: I played a bit before and after watching the movie, and I'm already hooked. For 2 bucks, you'll be telling yourself "Just another try" for hours. I'm gonna play it again when I'm done typing this. Addictive and fun! Get it!

Controls -
Pros: The controls are two buttons, but the nice thing is, there is controller support, and you can use WASD and the directionals as well, so you can play it how you like. The gameplay is much more about timing, anyways.
Cons: Even just a super move button where you get powers for the combo level you reach, like a screen-clearing attack or a ridiculously over-the-top animated move or two, would have been cool, and would have upped the wow factor, like the movie.

Gameplay -
Pros: Difficult, but in the way that you want to keep trying over and over to master it. Also, no button-mashing allowed, since if you miss a hit, you not only lose your multiplier, but you risk losing a life. It reminds me of the Arkham combat system in 2 dimensions; very rhythmic with the combos, and each enemy has a different rhythm to beat it, whether it's a combination of different directions or a particular amount of hits per enemy, or even how far your hits knock an enemy back into the queue. 
Cons: After seeing the movie, I kinda wish there was more character variation (but I've only gotten to 90k points so maybe there is), perhaps some street thugs or laser raptors, or even different locations for fighting (like in the G*dd*amn Viking Age or the Mean Streets) where there would be different enemies. It could be like Miami Shark, where it just gets increasingly more ridiculous and the enemies fill the screen and the things you fight get crazier, like in the movie. Just sayin'. 

Music -
Pros: It's rad as hell. From the movie, obviously, but they nailed it in the movie, so there you have it.
Cons: I mean, it loops, but that's what you get. Also, there's no option to shut it off which kind of sucks for someone like me who likes to supply their own soundtrack.

Graphics -
Pros: Perfect. Feels retro, but polished. 
Cons: It gets a little hard to combo when you have a bunch of dudes up in your shiz, but then again, I think that's kind of the point. Also, screen flash can be a bit headache-inducing and some graphics cover up the action so you don't know how close you are to an enemy, which could mean coming up short and getting hit.

Verdict: 9/10. Could be crazier, but super fun in its current state. Also hoping for Steam Cards and achievements, though I have a feeling this is the finished product, but... a man can dream.
Totally worth 2 bucks if you have 2 bucks. If you don't, get 2 bucks. Then have 2 bucks to spend on it.

16050986.review:
Much like the film upon which it is based, experiencing Kung Fury: Street Rage is not an intellectual pursuit. Behind its attractively retro flair, complete with simulated bulbous low resolution Cathode Ray Tube display, stylized chiptune music, and sprite graphics, is an unforgiving test of pure reflex. The more you think while playing this game, the worse you'll do! There are only three buttons you need worry about: Right, Left, and Pause. Humorously, pausing the game takes it to a simulated blue screen of death, also providing you with the means to exit the game (pressing start again), causing the screen to warp and snowcrash. 

While individual mileage may vary, I find that the wide variety of animations that Kung Fury can unleash to represent your simple one-button attacks to be amusing enough to completely override any semblence of boredom in the otherwise extremely simple concept of the game's mechanics. Its simplicity borders on elegance, or perhaps even meets it, as I do not believe they could have added anything to the game that wouldn't somehow damage the experience. 

It boils down to this: enemies run at you from either side and you must attack them as they get close. Most are one-hit mooks easily dispatched, but as play progresses tougher and more complicated enemies arrive--ones that require frantic combinations of right and left attacks to take down, as more and more foes flock and swarm in an attempt to overwhelm you. And overwhelm you they will.

You can take three hits and then it's game over, to start again. There are no power ups, no way to heal yourself, no way to expand your character's capabilities, no other levels; this game is just You, Your Reflexes, and the High Score. Maybe it's not the most immersive experience in the world, but without a doubt it's one of the purest executions of a game ever expressed. 

The fact that it's so aesthetically polished--not MERELY poor graphics but an entire suite of stylistic touches like glitches, rendering artifacts, all meant to evoke the limited hardware capacities of ages gone by--makes the whole experience an unexpected treat. Give it a whirl; you don't have anything to lose! ...except for maybe two bucks. But I humbly submit that it's worth that much.

The mechanics are straight from One Finger Death Punch, but they work great and they really fit in with the theme and idea of the movie (only thing that could fit the movie better is if they had a talk with the people who did Far Cry Blood Dragon and combined their efforts for the ultimate 80s game). Highly advised for people who enjoyed the [url=https://youtu.be/bS5P_LAqiVg]movie[/url] and have a couple of dollars to spend. Be advised this game has only one stage and no options menu at the time of this review.

P.S. The [url=https://youtu.be/bS5P_LAqiVg]movie[/url] is free to view on Youtube.

P.S.S. The movie is pure 80s throwback gold I suggest watching it and supporting the studio behind it by getting the movie on VHX

16048065.review:
After the awesomeness that was the movie, I really wanted this game to (at least) be decent; however, I can't in good conscience recommend it because there's another game out there that's almost exactly the same except better in every way.

It's essentially a janky version of One Finger Death Punch, in that there's only two buttons: attack the guy on your left, and attack the guy on your right. Much like OFDP, you start out fighting some basic enemies who only take one hit, and then mix in other enemies who take multiple hits and occasionally dodge to the other side.

The problem is, I'm not entirely sure the developers ever played OFDP - or if they did, they didn't take the time to understand what made OFDP nearly perfect. 

See, the key insight that OFDP had is that there's a rhythm to kung-fu fights; there's an ebb and flow, a flurry of action followed by a moment of quiet. This game doesn't have any of that; it goes at the exact same rhythm forever. 

And that's completely aside from the fact that One Finger Death Punch took the concept significantly further than this game has, with unlockable skills, weapons, boss fights, and special attacks that send you leaping across the battlefield. 

If you already own One Finger Death Punch and want to know how this game is different, go play Blind Survival mode with no skills enabled, then:  

[list]
[*] Pretend there's no weapons 
[*] Pretend there's no boss fights
[*] Pretend the game refuses to be played in a window
[*] Pretend the screen flashes on [b]every single strike[/b], which honestly made me feel kinda sick
[*] Pretend there's no casual racism (which is probably the only upside) 
[/list]

And you'll have an idea of what this game is like. 

I'm not saying this due to some misguided idea that this game is "ripping off" OFDP - I'm actually very happy that another game's picked up on the ingenious mechanic. I'm just disappointed that this game is strictly worse than One Finger Death Punch.

At first I was expecting the gameplay of the classic 2D beat-em-up, and I promptly got my rear end handed to me.

Then I took a couple minutes to examine the gameplay, and realized it's both very simple, and yet very challenging.

Using an Xbox 360 controller, you really only need 2 buttons, either X and B, or left and right on a control pad. From there it becomes a matter of timing your hits to the enemies on screen, based on which side they're on and how close they are to you. Three hits and your down, and your foes are unforgiving of the slightest mistake.

This game is quickly addictive once you get the hang of it, and well worth the two bucks it takes to buy it.

16045757.review:
Les graphismes et animations de ce Kung Fury: Street Rage sont vraiment sympa, il n'y a pas à dire, de même que le post-traitement de l'image, façon tube cathodique des jeux d'arcade des années 1980/90.

Cependant, la jouabilité est surprenante : gauche pour un coup à gauche ; droite pour un coup à droite ; et c'est tout. Les hordes d'ennemis ne sont pas adaptées, car plutôt que déterministes, ce qui aurait permis au jeu d'être un jeu de rythme, semblent plutôt aléatoires. Du coup, on se retrouve à devoir gérer plusieurs ennemis en même temps des deux côtés, sans rien pouvoir y faire, ce qui casse le compteur de combos, et donc le score, les seuls leviers pouvant inciter à continuer le jeu.

Mais peut-être est-ce fait exprès ? Souvenez-vous des adaptations de films en jeux vidéo des années 1980/90, dont E.T.,  qui à lui seul a failli couler toute l'industrie ! Pour les plus jeunes d'entre nous, c'est simple : le film avait beau être bon, le jeu était (presque) toujours (très) mauvais. Et pour cause : les développeurs recevaient la commande pour le jeu au dernier moment, sans souvent rien connaître du scénario, le tout devant sortir en même temps que le film, quelques mois, voire quelques semaines après le début du projet.

En cela, du coup, cette adaptation d'un (plutôt) bon court-métrage s'inspirant des clichés des années 1980/90 en un (très) mauvais jeu vidéo est fidèle aux lieux communs de cette époque. Toutefois, c'est loin des attentes des joueurs qui ont aimé des jeux rétros beaucoup, beaucoup plus aboutis.

Si vous cherchez un bon jeu, évitez d'urgence cette bouze. Pour le même prix, achetez-vous un café. Il durera plus longtemps ! Et si vous avez vraiment envie de retrouver cette époque sous forme  vidéo-ludique parodique, essayez plutôt l'excellent Broforce. Un bien meilleur placement, en termes de jouabilité !

16044994.review: Сегодня вышел долгожданный мной фильм KUNG FURY . Ждал я его из-за чумового трейлера. Из-за незабываемого саундтрека от David Hasselhoff. Из-за… да из-за ностальгии по 80-м, чёрт подери! В кино собраны все клише, все амплуа персонажей, вся атмосфера тех годов, доведены чуть ли не до абсурда, но этот гротеск не во вред памяти о годах, а скорее наоборот. Кино – квинтэссенция всех ностальгических воспоминаний... Но, простите, я тут не о фильме же хотел поговорить, а про игру. А Kung Fury: Street Rage – это как раз небольшой бонус к кино. Игрушка пародирует (или копирует) игровые автоматы 80-х. В ней главный герой как раз тот самый коп из фильма, что намерен набить морду самому крутому кунгфу-мастеру – Адольфу Гитлеру. Короче, игра – такой же угар, как и её старший брат. По геймплею это beat 'em up. Классический, с брутальными ударами, накаченными мужиками и бабами, которых надо избивать. А ещё там есть роботы и прочие персонажи из фильма. И всё это стилизировано под экран игрального автомата. Вообщем, если вы такой же любитель 80-х, как и я, если вы ждали ленту, на которой основана игра, если вы любите игровые автоматы и Beat 'em up – берите не задумываясь! Всем остальным, думаю, стоит обойти стороной проект. Хотя… Короче, смотрите трейлер игры и решайте сами! А я лично отправляюсь бить морды фашистам!
